attributes.title: Hasbro: Feel Like A Kid Again
summary: Hasbro has had a good 10 year return.
The dividends have been growing at a extremely healthy rate.
Will Hasbro still be a good investment even if the dividend growth rate drops as low as 5%?

attributes.content:
I honestly thought that toys were a thing of the past and kids these days were into Xboxes, Nintendo hand-helds, and mobile phones. I forgot one thing. I grew up. I am out of touch with the youngsters. It only took a photograph of my nephew playing with a teddy bear and those little race cars to realize that kids will always want to play make-believe at that age, at least that is how I remember it with my Sonic and Woody dolls.

In that respect, I feel that Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) has this niche area down pat. Now, you don't have to understand little kids. That is Hasbro's task. What you should understand is that over a 10 year period, this company has produced fantastic returns.

The chart below shows that since 2006 the stock went from 20 dollars to its current 80 dollars.

(Source: ThinkorSwim)

But, I don't want you to consider Hasbro for its price appreciation. I want you to consider it for its dividends. In fact, the dividend increases are pretty consistent.

If we chart the dividends, we can see a nice clean trend.

(Source: yCharts)

Interestingly enough, the 5 year trend is consistently higher. This is a metric that popular SA author David Van Knapp uses. The idea is that you want to see consistent growth.

According to the DripInvesting.org spreadsheet, the following metrics show that the dividends appear sustainable. (However, the current 10 year growth rate may not be.)

  • The current dividend yield is between 2 to 2.5 percent, which is a typical yield for dividend paying companies in general.
  • The payout ratio is 53.4%, which means about half are paid out to shareholders and half remain with the company. I have seen as much as 75% maximum recommended for a company to pay out in earnings and still grow the dividends. However, I am personally comfortable with about 50% because I feel the company will not be able to grow if most of the earnings are given to shareholders.
  • The 1, 3, 5, and 10 year growth rates are 7.1%, 9.5%, 13.8%, and 18.6%, respectively. Although these numbers are currently high, I do not want to be optimistic and hope for these kind of growth rates to continue. Given that the growth rates for the 1, 3, and 5 year are less than the 10 year average, it makes me believe that there is a tendency for a slower growth. The 10% annual growth that dividend growth investors seek might be iffy. However, the growth will most certainly be above the rate of inflation.

Assuming that inflation gets to the historical 2% level, the nominal increase from dividends assuming annualized growth rates between 5 to 9% but below 10% for the next 10 years are the following:

(Source:Self-created)

In addition, I will assume that 100 shares were bought. Thus, the total return from the dividends assuming the stock price stays at 80 dollars is the following:

(Source:Self-created)

(Note: 2016 dividends were only used to calculate growth values. This model assumes you start receiving dividends from 2017 going forward.)

While the total return appears juicy, pay attention to the annualized return. The difference is marginal because the annualized return from dividends is between 3 to 3.5%,which means to get the historical, total annualized return of 10%, the stock price needs to increase by 6 to 7% annually. This is very feasible.

In any one of these scenarios, about 33% of the annualized returns comes from Hasbro's dividends assuming a 10% historical return. This tells me that even if Hasbro's dividends fail to grow at the desired annual 10% growth rate, returns from dividends will still be very attractive. Historically, 33% of total annual returns have come from dividends.
